posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27937936
It's an evolutionary tactic to avoid letting autists breed lol.

Fr though, we flirt for a reason.
We're social animals. We need other people. We need to be liked. We have an innate desire to be accepted by others.
Hints allow us to communicate our potentially risky or unacceptable ideas, with the lowered likelihood of being outright rejected and possibly ostracised by the crowd. Ironically, they help us to 'be ourselves' around others in a safer way.

Think of it this way: if you hate the joos, you're probably not gonna stand on a table an heil hitler at work. You'll get fucking fired.
Instead, you make jokes and hint subtly that you hate the joos while talking shit with your coworkers. Then you look around to see whether any of your coworkers have that sparkle of a true Brother in their eyes. Then you know that you can talk outright with that coworker about how much you hate jews, because you know it's safe.

Flirting is similar.
It feels bad to be rejected. It can be socially damaging to be outright rejected. It can fuck your self-esteem up to get rejected. So you flirt to hint that you like the person, and if you notice them flirting back, you go ahead and ask them on a date. If they don't flirt back, you know you've been rejected, but the sting is less painful, and you're not embarrassed by the failure.

I know it sounds retarded, but that's just how this shit works. We're social creatures. It's important to learn how to understand one another via gestures and hints. It's just how we function.

I understand why you're frustrated over it. But it's just one of those things that you're gonna have to get good at, because it's not going away.
You gotta learn this skill, man. If you really struggle with this shit, get into therapy or something and ask for help navigating social situations and flirting. It's a necessary skill for life.

There’s nothing wrong with wanting to perform a little, but remember that it can’t just be you. She doesn’t want to feel like you’re conceited.

Thanks for elaborating on your escalation.
It all depends on the venue and the situation, but the easiest way is to find a reason to initiate contact. The early pick up artists of the mystery era learned magic tricks for this. I find that cheesy and it never works as well as they say it does. I recommend asking to see her finger nails if they’re painted. Or if you can somehow figure a way to get her to feel the cloth on your sleeve, try that. Your main goal is a light touch in an inoffensive area. You don’t go directly to the leg or back.
To add more sexual flair, try and find a way to get her to think she offered it first. Do this by bringing up topics that can go in a sexual way, but never make them sexual yourself. A good example here is to bring up something like how you like I sleep, or what a good morning is like. If she started to add in talk of last relationships that’s a cue to start responding with “oh I once had a girlfriend that was like that!” as you get more familiar the sex part will come. But by that point you’ll need to decide what kind of girl she is. There’s the kind they only want experienced men and there’s the kind that want modesty. No one wants a virgin.
Meaning, if your body count is 20, say it’s only been about 5, that way you’re not new but you aren’t fresh. She will make it clear who she is before you need to establish this

The main advice of the book is to live for yourself, and go for what you want in life. What you really want deep down, well beyond the point you would normally consider selfish, intrusive, or even mean, and not whatever your upbringing thinks is expected or proper. Seek conflict to resolve issues, instead of shutting up and doing something you don't like to avoid conflict. That has carryover into all of social life.

The book Models will reaffirm that position, and go even further by saying that it's actually good to offend some people, to polarize them quickly and force them to choose if they vibe with you or not. By laying all the cards of your personality on the table, she will either conclude things quickly knowing she won't like you, or she'll really like you a lot. And the you she likes is the real, honest you. Even if most women don't like your personality, the few who do will actually like the real you. A win/win that saves time and creates better bonds. Furthermore, simply having the balls to disagree or offend can be very attractive to women (the whole "girls love assholes" trope, which is true).

Those books pair very well with each other.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>27936976
Based and dad-pilled
Sounds like she's going through it.

I'm really depressed at the moment (my dad doesn't know - it would kill him). I go to my dad's house every week to play dnd with my family. He always asks me if I want to stay the night and he'll cook me dinner. He always says "it's no trouble, you're always welcome". It always makes me happy to be loved and cared for like that.
The other day, I was venting to my dad about troubles at work, and to cheer me up, he bought me some bourbon lol.
I love my dad.

Show your daughter that you love her. Invite her over, and spend time with her. Cook her a nice meal. Pour her a beer or bourbon or whatever you guys drink. Do something fun together. Go out and shoot something or play cards or watch TV together. Afterwards, invite her over again and let her know that you're always happy to see her.
You have no idea what a difference that makes. Even if you're the only one who'll ever love her like that, you're still someone who loves her. Make sure she receives as much as you have to give.

And check up on her from time to time. If this is out of character and she's struggling badly, she probably needs those little check-ins.
If she's really struggling mentally and she's normally a stoic person, she might be embarrassed to feel like she's worried you, or that you need to 'babysit' her with a daily call or something. So try to frame your sudden check-ins as something entirely different. Play up the old man act and pretend you need help working 'the netflix' lmao. Ask her over for dinner. The next day, call to confirm that you got her arrival time correct, so you can time dinner appropriately. Send her a meme or something, idk. Just find an excuse to spend time with her and remind her that you're thinking of her.

And when you say 'goodbye', avoid saying 'goodbye'. Say 'talk to you later' or 'see you tomorrow'.
You'd be surprised how much weight that has.

I hope your girl is ok, man. And you too.

Hi,

This isn't a post looking for sympathy, but rather a cold logical discussion regarding suicide. I firmly believe that suicide should be a human right that everyone should be entitled to take. Having come to this conclusion I find this choice to be the best decision I can make in my life

I am a 20-year-old man who comes from an abusive home. I have pdd-nos, otherwise specified as autism spectrum disorder. This naturally has weakened my social skills, and my emotions as well. I've never felt loved, nor do I love anyone. I am strictly asocial, aromantic, and asexual. With this in mind, I believe I have nothing to look forward to, especially considering that I live in the anti-intellectual shithole that is the US. A place that is prejudiced against, atheists, introverts, blacks, and everything that I am.

Furthermore, I believe I am a danger to others. I do not care morally if I hurt, kill, or maim humans, but rather would not suffer the consequences of my twisted, deranged, deviant behavior. At the same time, I do not feel I care enough about dying to actually become an hero. I feel the need to put myself in a place where I am scared of the consequences of something I've done to the point where I have to take my life. How can I reach that point?

Thanks,

Anon

posts.name: Anonymous

>20
>I have nothing to look forward to

Hi Anon, I'm 37. To me, this is like a little baby saying that life isn't worth living.

You are an angsty 20 year old, going through some difficult feelings, As time goes on, you will feel better and find your place in life. Your thoughts and feelings, and attitudes towards others will change as well.

Try to relax and take things one day at a time. Life isn't that bad. You don't have all the answers to life, you have just started living. Take a look outside yourself, and off the computer and you'll see that the world is big enough that everyone can have a place in it, even people like you.

Good luck.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27936768
I was kind of like this as a kid. And my younger brother went through almost the exact same thing.

This is gonna sound retarded, but your brother might have anxiety (either he has an anxiety disorder, or he's just an anxious person, idk).
It's really fucking common for kids to express anxiety via explosive temper tantrums, because they don't know how to handle their bullshit any other way.
It's less common in teenagers, but it's definitely a strong possibility that your brother might be going through some shit that he doesn't know how to handle, and exploding is the only outlet that he has.

When I my brother and I were kids, we'd lose our fucking minds and throw tantrums whenever we lost a game too many times. I can't speak for my brother, but in my case, my thought process was "I can't do this. I can't do anything right. I'm useless. I'm a fuckup. The world is out to get me. God spits in my face." I didn't like not being 'in control' of the game, so I was a real bitch when I got my ass kicked. I wouldn't even be angry. I just needed an outlet for the... tension? I guess that's the word. So I'd cry or scream or hit things, or hit myself. My brother once threw a controller. He also used to be a real screecher when he lost games.
Both of us also reacted to OTHER stresses in a similar way. We'd try to stay calm, but would eventually explode. We had no other way of managing the stress.

Our parents eventually put us in sports, which made a HUGE difference.

Frankly, I think the best thing you can do is help your brother find a healthy outlet for his anger. Don't shame him or yell at him. Stay calm and distract him with something else. If you see him getting wound up, tell him (nicely) that it's time for a break. Praise him whenever you see him making progress. Get him into sports or into a productive hobby too. That shit is good for you.

>>27938136
I have genital herpes in the vaginal area.
It's literally a non-issue.

I freaked out at first because I was scared that my (very new) boyfriend was gonna dump me. But I'm not a slimy, cowardly piece of shit, so I bit the bullet and told him immediately. I basically told him what it meant, apologised for the bad news, encouraged him to get tested, and told him "this is a permanent thing, so I understand if you're no longer interested in dating me."
He must have been interested, because he tested negative, then he stuck around for the next 3 years.

At first I was paranoid about having sex because I didn't want him to catch it, and I always felt a little guilty afterwards. For the first few weeks, I always double-checked that he really WANTED to have sex, before proceeding. I didn't do this verbally every time lol, but I'd sort of pull away and let him lead. If he was enthusiastic about it, I took it for consent and acceptance of the risk. When he didn't get sick, I stopped being paranoid, though I did make him get yearly blood tests, just for my own peace of mind. During that entire relationship, he never caught it. Lucky bastard was one of the few people who are immune to that shit.

In 10 years, I have never had another outbreak. I haven't even had an ITCH.
Herpes is only really an issue if you're dating an immunocompromised person, because it can fuck them up. But for the majority of people, you get one shitty outbreak, then you're fine.

IME, people don't really judge you for it. I haven't dated since that last guy, but a few male friends have hit on me at some point in time, knowing damn well that I've got herpes. So obviously people aren't bothered by it.

Some people will of course reject you for it. But as long as you're cool about it, and informative and respectful, most people will be willing to date you.
You're ok, man. Don't stress. Trust me - it's not the death sentence you think it is.

Purchase a tongue scraper online and use it regularly when waking up and before going to bed.. Any white shit on your tongue is bacteria and fungus and it needs to come off, it is the biggest source of stench in you mouth by far.

You should be flossing regularly, it's not a one time thing. Every single night, between every tooth on each side. Do this attentively in the mirror to make sure you're getting all food chunks out (and in the sink, don't get them on your floor, nasty).

Additionally use an electric toothbrush to make sure you're getting good cleaning tooth coverage. Brush your gums and tongue too when you're brushing as a second pass after the tongue scraping to make sure you got everything. Again, you should be focused in the mirror while doing this.

Ensure you're going to the dentist regularly for checkups and cleanings, at least once every six months. Get any needed work done immediately.

Drink water frequently.

When you need to smell good, avoid eating fragrant foods like fish, cheese, garlic, onions, and all fermented foods (olives, kimchi, pickles, etc.), or at least commit to brushing your teeth before eg. any planned events or romance

Before events where you need to have extra "good breath", keep a pack or canister of mint gum in your car and chew it on the way. Additionally, 30 minutes prior to the event, use a mint mouthwash.

If you're doing all the above religiously, I don't care how bad your genes are, your breath should smell good. Failures to smell good are a failure to observe one or more aspects of the above routine religiously.

OP, I'm going to let you in on a secret that will blow your mind. I'm going to assume a few things.
>1) You're the average man, and will thus properly date 6 women over the course of your lifetime (you're on number 2 after about a year).
>2) You want to maximise your chances of finding the best woman out of all the woman you date.
What you're doing here is somewhat lucky - you have the option to compare two "candidates", and can date either one. Unfortunately you won't be able to do this with all six.

How do you make sure you maximise your chances of getting the best of the six people? Thankfully, it's been reduced to math:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secretary_problem

The TL;DR of the above is that you should reject the first 2 people you date automatically, and then only accept a woman as a long-term partner if she is better than the first two. So in your case, date blue, but don't worry if it doesn't work out long run. If she moves back to China, just keep dating until you find someone better than both of them, and reject anyone worse.

The number you reject depends on how many dating partners you'll have over the course of your life:
>Worse than average (4 or fewer) - reject the first 1
>Average (5-6) - reject the first 2.
>Better than average (7-9) - reject the first 3.
>Doubly better than average (10-12) - reject the first 4.

While it might be comforting to think that everything happens for a quantifiable reason and that therefore you can prevent suboptimal outcomes with enough data, it simply isn't the case. The best thing you can do is try and be a loving, considerate partner and be as honest and true to yourself as you can in the relationship, that way no matter what happens, you have no regrets.

Plus, I also like omelettes without onion, but I don't think I'd leave someone over them making me one with onion. I wouldn't attribute the breakup to that specifically, it was likely a combination of things, most of which were out of your control.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27935976
It might be a good idea to have a frank discussion with your mum. Don't bring it up when she's already angry and arguing. Wait until she's in a good mood.
Let her know that you've noticed this new trend, and you're worried about her. Ask her if everything is ok, and if there's anything you can do for her.

Try not to get argumentative or defensive in response when she (inevitably) starts getting combative about what you're saying.
Try to be kind and listen to her. Try to hear her out - even when she's saying some wild shit.
Idk, but I'm trying to put myself in your mum's shoes and imagining how I'd have to be feeling or thinking in order to WANT to fight over stupid shit. IME when I feel like starting fights over dumb shit, it's usually a response to feeling wronged or stressed - especially when I feel powerless about something. (Note: I don't actually DO this shit. I've had this issue since I was little. I've learned to manage that combative bullshit in a healthier way over the years). If your mum is in a similar boat, maybe she would benefit from having you sit down and really give her the time of day and let her vent. Try to tease more words out of her and let her talk. Try to get to the root of why she's saying this dumb shit and starting fights. Try to work with her, not battle her. You feel me?

If you feel like you won't be able to get through to her verbally, try writing her a letter. Or sending her a lengthy text message or something.

It's also a good idea to just... spend more time with your mum. Try to make sure she's happy and feels loved. It'll be hard when she's acting like a prick, but if she's going through some shit and is struggling, your presence may make a world of difference. Whether she's mentally ill or just having a rough time, that's always a helpful thing to have in her life.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27937885

As for what to do when you're already in one of these arguments: I guess the best thing to do is give her the benefit of the doubt (to avoid unfairly dismissing her when she makes an initial stupid comment that you don't agree with). But once you're certain that she's just being a retard and causing fights for no reason, simply tell her "I want to talk to you, mum, but I'm not gonna sit here and let you be combative and turn things into arguments that don't need to be arguments. Please stop. I want to have happy conversations with you. Not this."
Then try to diffuse the situation by focusing on something else. You can talk about the issue she's complaining about later, when she's calm.
If she doesn't stop, simply walk away and let her talk to herself instead.
Make this the new 'normal' way of handling arguments with your mum. Eventually she'll learn that she needs to sort her shit out and act right if she wants you to ever listen to her.
Even if she's only doing this because she's mentally ill, setting boundaries and walking away when she crosses them is still beneficial to her, because it may help her realise that her behaviour is affecting her relationships and she needs to get some real help for it.
Also, this is better for YOU, too.

There are no perfect people and equally there are no perfect relationships. All you can do is be honest and earnest with people, approaching them with kindness and trying to accept their faults.

Objectively, the person doesn't matter in the beginning, attachment, bonding and ultimately love can be had with anyone. However once those things have been achieved it matters subjectively who the person is.

The relationship isn't separate to the people inside of it.

Generally, people regret the decision not have children when they're in their sixties, not their thirties.

The only happy old people I've ever met have had large families, or have had small families but came from money. Exception being old people who spent their later years helping other peoples' kids, generally ones who came from their own families such as nieces, nephews, or cousins.

Of course there are some outliers who have something in them calling them to live a barren, childless lifestyle for the sake of a higher calling, but unless you're very certain you fall into that later category, I think generally choosing not to have children is a mistake often left unrealized until it's too late.

Choosing not to have children just to pursue your own feckless hedonism is a purely foolish endeavor, and people who live this lifestyle and say otherwise are either coping or will be coping in ten years.

Of course, having children is something you should only do if/when you're ready, but for most people it is the primary source of meaning in this world over the course of their lives. Why shouldn't it be? They're your continuation. Your legacy in this world. If you have them in a loving union, they're the symbol of your love brought to fruit. Your little contribution to the interlinking chain of bio-cultural DNA linking us back to the primordial waters we crawled out of. Your participation in the cosmic cycle of life. Your chance to be a part of the future you're never going to see. Even then, they are so much more, because they are and will become their own people, and if you do your job right they will succeed you, and surpass you, and I have never seen a man with greater joy in his eyes then when they are filled with pride for his own son.

Most people with normal hormones get baby fever at some point, yeah. It's only natural to want kids at some point in your life.
Childfree people are common in their 20s. I'm 27 and almost everyone I know is 'childfree'. But after 30, it seems like most childfree people change their minds about becoming parents. So true 'childfree' people are pretty rare in later years, from what I've seen.

>Have you ever seen a happy, stable, childless couple?
Yes, but these people were all in their 20s, and I don't really know many people older than me without kids, so I can't really speak for whether these happy young couples will continue to be childfree later in life. Like I said, most people change their minds later on. (Though the difference in attitudes between the generations may be a cultural thing, rather than a 'hormones making you baby crazy' thing).
I think in order to remain happy and fulfilled as a 'childfree' couple, it's important to have other goals and responsibilities to keep you ticking. If life gets too easy and loses meaning, it's easy to become stagnant and depressed.

I love kids. I love being an aunt, and I am good with kids in general. I've had baby fever - usually around my period. But the hormonal urges have always been weaker than the urge to remain childless. At least, so far. Maybe it'll change in the future, in the right circumstances. But desu I think not.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I lost interest in anime and video games for a long time. I still had my other hobbies, and still have them, but I lost interest in those.
I still continued to play games on and off, but it didn't occupy my time like it once did. But this year, I got back into Terraria and I played Kirby's Adventure. For both of these games, I felt genuine fun playing video games for the first time. I played solo, as I always do, and I'm fine with that. Gaming is something deeply personal for me.
But anime it's been a while. And I'm not a weeb like I used to be. But many years after I had gotten it recommended to me by a friend and after having been somewhat spoiled, I watched Neon Genesis Evangelion and the End of Evangelion. All in a short amount of time. It's probably a cliché, but I've never seen an anime like this until now. Touching stuff, sure, but I mostly watched anime for laughs. I watched it subbed on Netflix, and the voice acting was good. The music was good. But the story I do believe has the highest stakes of any anime, since it's about what it means to be human. I relate to Asuka more than Shinji, without the trauma, but I certainly get Shinji's problem with escapism. However I'm at a point I already was aware of it. I'm also much happier than when I was 14. I wonder what it would have been like if weeb, friendless 13-14 year old me had watched it. I certainly didn't have the self-awareness to have seen Asuka in me. Would she have been my waifu? It the end it was Misato. But I would certainly see myself in Shinji. I have to take to heart . Have any of you been moved by that series? A lot of people said it changed their life. I just crammed the last episodes and the movies in one day yesterday (not the rebuild ones yet), and I'd started a little over one week ago. Reminds me of when I spent my summer of 13 in the basement watching Naruto instead of doing much of anything else. I still do escapism, but I go out more.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27937134
>antisocial
Sorry, not to be pedantic, but the word you're looking for is asocial. Antisocial refers to a very specific personality disorder, colloquially known as sociopathy. I'm sure that's not what you meant.

>I get told I have autism for sure.
Have you gotten diagnosed? If not, then it's just people's opinion. And most people are misinformed anyway. A misinformed opinion isn't something we should care too much for.

>I don’t like feeling like I have to prove myself to others and so I just stay silent.
Realize that feeling like you have to prove yourself to others comes from inside of you rather than coming from outside of you. There are ways and methods of realigning your thought patterns so that you no longer feel any "outside" compulsion.

I don't do so well articulating myself since I'm on the spectrum myself, but maybe in failing to articulate I could instead share and relate. I have the felt the way you have described. Plenty. Acting and conversing in unconventional ways (at least when I'm not masking). Have not been forthright and have been silent until I was forced to learn assertiveness. It's a long road and journey, but you really can learn to live for yourself with confidence, and to not be--for lack of a better term--enslaved by what you perceive to be the expectations of people who, quite frankly, do not matter in the grand scheme of things. Those people do not define your worth as a person. Only you do.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27937349
It’s a start, Anon! Think of it sorta like a diet. Most people don’t last very long on their diets if they try to replace all their happy-chemical-sources with rice cakes and kale and vegan cardboard-esque bullshit overnight. Even with that example, you crave sugar less and less the less you have it. You can get there by having little, lessening increments, and therefore having less cravings as time goes by instead of having huuuge cravings right away as soon as you cut it out.
Your brain is wired to work this way. You aren’t lazy or inferior to anyone else. Your brain is doing what it thinks it is supposed to for your happiness and survival. But it can’t tell the difference between those things and just plain comfort-zone rotting.
Make the internet work for *you*. Make your brain work for *you*. You don’t even have to learn to love the feeling of resistance and difficulty —at the very least you just need to train yourself to recognize them as signs that you’re doing what’s best for yourself. But yeah. Try to put your longterm happiness/well-being and habits that contribute to that above instant gratification. Step by step.

We met in high school and now I'm a few years into college so we've been friends for a while. He's still living with his family since he can't figure out what he's going to do with his life. I've always have gone over what I would say if someone was considering suicide, like acting as the tough guy or logical person in the situation but when I was talking to him all of that "preparation" fell apart the moment he brought it up. I was completely helpless in this situation and was freaking out the entire time I was talking to him, knowing that what I say here could determine whether he ends it or not. I talked to him about my insecurities and all that shit to hammer in the fact that we're all not perfect etc.. but it all seems futile when he just ends off with "Goodbye bro".

I call him the next day and he picks up completely normal, maybe a bit more quiet than usual. I really fucking hate him for doing that. He put me through all of that bullshit and then told me his goodbyes and shit, which made me stress throughout the entire night and come to terms with the fact that that's the last time I could be talking to him. It's a shit feeling coming to terms with the fact that this is the last time you will ever be able to talk to that friend.
Apologies for all the cliches or whatever you find in here or cringe at some parts I just told it how it is to me.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Naltrexone for alcoholism treatment

An addict wanting and trying to quit is a case of the rational mind deciding to stop, while the autonomous processes of the mind create cravings. Its why people have such a hard time losing weight. Rational mind chooses to lose weight and eat less, autonomous mind sends craving signals. You can understand something is bad and decide to quit, but you still go up against powerful urges/cravings. Worth noting is that gambling, sex, compulsive overeating, alcoholism and drug addiction are a cluster of similar disorders. A malfunction of the brain's "reward center". See for yourself: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18241634/

Naltrexone is a helpful medication to remove the cravings. Classed as an opiate-antagonist (binds to endorphin receptors w/out "high"), Naltrexone comes in a once-monthly injection or daily pills. Absent insurance, injection is expensive and pills are inexpensive. Public health clinics, aka "community clinics" receive federal and state cost-reduction grants to serve people who lack insurance. Sliding-fee scale for most services and in the case of Naltrexone injection, often free. In the U.S. you can call 211 in most cities, a direct line to United Way. They will help you locate such a clinic. Also some anti-depressants and other psychotropic medications can help. Addicts tend to have mood or other psychiatric issues that are called "co-morbid factors". A doctor at a "community clinic" can help with that also. Naltrexone is typically taken daily for 3+ months.

Drugs.com has 500+ positive reviews about Naltrexone from actual alcoholics.

"Medical detox" refers to a doctor prescribing librium or valium for a few days to get you safely off alcohol. It works and its painless. Trying to "taper down" WITH alcohol is slow and extremely painful. Most doctors will readily offer you a medical detox prescription.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27936480
Marketing is hard and honestly to a point soul draining. People are bombarded with ads screaming at them. Repition of brand exposure builds consumer confidence.

Targeted online ads are an option but they're expensive. And more expensive than sticker. Online advertisers are rampant with bot fraud but they don't try too hard to detect it. Goes against their business model of selling you impressions.

Small local communities, or online ones of making an impression are good. Talk about what you do. Offer samples. Try to build a word of mouth audience. Effectively pay your customers to try your product.

There won't be one answer. You'll have to do multiple avenues. And it'll cost you. Don't intend to live off this anytime soon.

posts.sub: Opening up to my parents, should I even do it?
posts.com: I again got into an argument I had a couple times with my parents. Something I've had since I was very young was that I shut myself off whenever my parents want to do what I'm watching, playing or doing. Even if it's completely innocuous. I see it as part of my own personal world, and I decide who gets access to that world. I don't want to show it to my parents, since even though they wouldn't judge me, (at least that's what they say, but I know it's not always the case), I don't want my parents to see my world unless I have no choice, in which case I can't even look at them in the eyes. As a result I talk to them a lot, but always small talk, and they notice. My dad in particular is distraught by it. Over the years, especially since I'm in college, I just want more and more to be independent and move away so they don't bother me. I know it'll sound wrong, but I don't think my parents are entitled to know me just because I'm their son. The thing is they're so different from me and I know for a fact I would have never become friends with them had we met at the same age. Well, my brother has a fraught relationship with them, doesn't respect them, but he's very honest with them. I have a lot of things I'm passionate about, and a future, but it's like my goal is that one day, I'll see my parents on holidays, talk a bit, but that would be it. I know it'd hurt them and probably me as well, but I don't want them in my life. The thing is like most people in this country, they pressure you without being blunt, I don't really feel at ease here, but moving out the country, one of my life goals, wouldn't help me since I'd be terribly lonely. My extended family isn't much better.
